titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, International Division, Middle East and Africa, Riyadh, Saudi Arabia Field Office Files
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, International Division, Middle East and Africa, Riyadh, Saudi Arabia Field Office Files FA643

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-09-16 12:08:48 -0400.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, International Division, Middle East and Africa, Riyadh, Saudi Arabia Field Office Files

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Ford Foundation archive was deposited at RAC in 2011. Ford Foundation records, correspondence, reports, program files and officers papers were transferred to, and accessioned by, RAC beginning in 2011. Accessions continue as necessary.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at https://rockarch.org/collections/access-and-request-materials/#citations

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Appendix A: Reports â€“ Unpublished reports written by Ford Foundation staff and consultants were removed from their original folders, scanned and transferred to the Archives' collection of staff and consultant reports. See Appendix A for a list of these reports and their specific assigned number. The reports are listed in alphabetical order by author. The assigned number may be used to access reports in the online catalog.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in 10 series by file type.
Series II. Legal and Budget Documents, 1965-1972
Series IV. Administrative Reform Program Files, 1965-1974
Series IX. Royal Decrees and Regulations, 1952-1972

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Records more than 10 years old are open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contents includes but is not limited to: correspondence, subject files, conference papers, budget files, films, program files and administrative records.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Ford Foundation maintained an office presence in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia from 1974 to 1977. The Foundation established the office in 1974 when it transferred Wesley Edwards, assistant to the Foundation's Representative to Beirut, Lebanon and part-time consultant to Saudi Arabia, to the country on a full-time basis. Wesley was appointed as an advisor to the Saudia Arabian Ministry of Education and was also made the Foundation's Representative to Saudi Arabia. Foundation activities in Saudi Arabia largely focused on education during this period (Middle East Program Plans, March 16, 1976, Ford Foundation records, Catalogued Reports, Reports 6262-9286 (FA739C), Report 009210).

However, the Ford Foundation's activities in Saudi Arabia extend back to 1963 when it signed an agreement with the Saudi Arabian Government to work with Saudi Arabia "in a mutual effort aimed toward the economic and social development of the Kingdom." This began the Foundation's assistance to the Saudi Arabian Administrative Reform Program. The Foundation contracted the Institute for International Education (IIE) to employ advisors for the program. Advisors were paid with Saudi Arabian funds but worked under the direction of the Ford Foundation (A Review of Administrative Reform in Saudi Arabia, 1972, Ford Foundation records, Catalogued Reports, Reports 3255-6261 (FA739B), Report 005557) The Administrative Reform Program ended in 1973.

In 1976, Wesley Edwards left his post and the Ford Foundation gave up its formal office space. It maintained a small apartment office where it housed it's files until 1977 when it complied with an order from the Saudi Arabian Ministry of Interior to close its office and leave the country (Saudi Arabia memo draft from Robert Edwards to McGeorge Bundy, March 7, 1977, Ford Foundation records, Catalogued Reports, Reports 9287-11774 (FA739D), Report 011051).

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Closed - File is restricted from scholarly access.
